issues.text: Whether in the exercise of the power of amendment the fundamental structure of the Constitution may be changed or even destroyed or whether the power is restricted to making modification within the framework of the original instrument for its better effectuation?

anchor.surface_text: On the findings the following, questions did number fall to be companysidered Whether in the exercise of the power of amendment the fundamental structure of the Constitution may be changed or even destroyed or whether the power is restricted to making modification within the framework of the original instrument for its better effectuation ?

arguments.claim: Fundamental rights are the primordial rights necessary for the development of human personality and given a transcendental position beyond the reach of Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: Per Subba, Rao, J., Shah, Sikri, Shelat and Vaidialingam, JJ. Fundamental rights are the primordial rights necessary for the development of human personality. They are the rights which enable a man to chalk out his own life in the manner he likes best.

arguments.claim: Parts III and IV constitute an integrated scheme where Directive Principles can be enforced without abridging fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Our Constitution, in addition to the well-known fundamental rights, also included the rights of minorities and other backward communities in such rights. The fundamental rights are given a transcendental position under our Constitution and are kept beyond the reach of Parliament.

arguments.claim: Article 32 makes the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamental rights itself a fundamental right.

holdings.text: Sajjan Singh v. State of Rajasthan, 1965 1 S.C.R. 933 reversed.

anchor.surface_text: Rajasthan, 1965 1 S.C.R. 933, reversed. Per Subba, Rao, J., Shah, Sikri, Shelat and Vaidialingam, JJ. Fundamental rights are the primordial rights

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous decision wrong; correct early to prevent erosion of fundamental rights.

holdings.text: The power of Parliament to amend the Constitution is derived from Arts. 245, 246 and 248 read with item 97 in List I.

anchor.surface_text: The power of Parliament to amend the Constitution is derived from Arts. 245, 246 and 248 read with item 97 in List I. The residuary power of Parliament can certainly take in the power to amend the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 368 prescribes procedure; power from legislative residuary powers.

holdings.text: A constitutional amendment is 'law' within the meaning of Article 13(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusive definition of 'law' in Art.13(2) covers amendments following legislative process.

holdings.text: Parliament has no power under Article 368 to amend Part III so as to abridge fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Article 368 in terms only prescribes various steps in the matter of amendment. The article assumes the power to amend found else where.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendments limited by Art.13(2); cannot abridge rights in Part III.

holdings.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling applies; 17th Amendment and prior amendments valid but future amendments cannot abridge fundamental rights.
